With extensive experience across many specialties and settings – technical, clinical, project management, leadership, informatics and more – our team delivers the comprehensive, can-do expertise you need in a Oracle Cerner HIT partner. Meet our team: All Leadership Team Business Development Resource Development Matt Terstriep, MBA Founder and Executive Advisor An accomplished leader with proven success across his 40+ year career in health IT, Matt founded our company in 2002. Having built this company on the vision of delivering stronger performance through expert Oracle Cerner technology integration and workflow optimization, Matt’s leadership continues to drive our culture, purpose and performance every day. Prior to founding HPG, Matt’s career highlights included sales, marketing and leadership positions at such organizations as Shared Medical Systems (now Cerner), Continental Healthcare Systems (now WellSky), and First Choice Consulting. He has an MBA in healthcare administration from the University of Illinois and is a longstanding member of HIMSS. Chad Terstriep, MBA Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board Chad Terstriep serves as Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board at HPG, leading the company’s strategic vision, financial oversight, and commitment to delivering exceptional value to both Associates and Customers. Appointed to this role in January 2025, Chad is dedicated to driving HPG’s long-term growth while upholding the company’s strong culture and core values. A respected leader with nearly two decades at HPG, Chad has been instrumental in shaping the company’s success. Since joining in 2007, he has held key leadership roles, including President, Senior Vice President of Strategic Services, Director of Resource Development, and Resource Development Executive. His leadership has been central to attracting and developing top talent, fostering strong customer partnerships, and expanding HPG’s service capabilities. Before joining HPG, Chad was a Regional Account Manager at AIM Healthcare Services (now part of UnitedHealthcare), where he worked with major healthcare organizations such as Mayo Clinic, Allina Health, and Hennepin County Medical Center. Chad holds a Bachelor’s degree in Communications from the University of Kansas and a Master’s degree in Business Administration from the University of St. Thomas. Andy Flynn, MT, ASCP President Andy is President of HPG, where he leads the day-to-day operations and drives the organization’s strategic direction. A founding partner and HPG charter member since 2002, Andy has played a pivotal role in the company’s growth and success. With a career that began as a medical technologist and expanded across three decades into health IT, Andy is fluent in both clinical and technical languages. His ability to translate complex concepts makes him an exceptional communicator across all levels of proficiency. His expertise in Oracle Cerner applications is extensive, having actively participated in over 30 implementations. Before joining HPG, Andy was a Senior Consultant at Park City Solutions and held multiple roles at Cox Health Systems, including Senior Business Analyst, Negative Certifying Scientist, and General Medical Technologist. He earned his bachelor’s degree in medical technology from Missouri State University. Randy Bullinger, CPA, CGMA, MBA Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer An HPG charter member and founding partner, Randy has served as our Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer since 2002. With more than three decades of leadership experience at the intersection of healthcare and finance, Randy is responsible for HPG’s financial health and human resource investments. Through his unique industry knowledge, broad financial expertise, and extensive compensation/benefit experience, Randy has a keen ability to research, select, manage and maintain vital programs that maximize the experience for all HPG team members, customers, suppliers and benefit programs. Prior to joining HPG, Randy’s career highlights include leadership roles in finance and administration at First Choice Consulting (now Park City Solutions), Via Christi Senior Services and Healthcare Data Systems. Randy holds an MBA from Wichita State University and bachelor’s degrees in business and accounting from the University of Kansas. Nancy Ward Senior Vice President, Business Development Nancy is a proven sales leader with extensive experience driving growth and business development in the highly competitive health IT market. She is responsible for ensuring HPG team members are fully engaged and our customers are receiving the support they need, when they need it. Nancy joined HPG in 2013 and has made numerous contributions to our success in her current role as Senior Vice President of Business Development, as well as her previous positions as Senior Resource Development Executive and Resource Development Director. Nancy’s health IT and leadership experience in sales, recruiting and business development spans more than three decades. Before joining HPG, Nancy held sales leadership positions at iPractice and Vitera Healthcare Solutions (formerly Sage). Joe Vanderbeek Senior Vice President, Consulting Services Since joining HPG in 2005, Joe has contributed to HPG’s success in numerous roles, from Senior Consultant to Support Center Director and his current role as Senior Vice President, Consulting Services. In this role, Joe is responsible for the professional development of our Cerner Consulting Experts and is responsible for the quality and delivery of our services. With a practical approach to business, the highest levels of professionalism and quality standards – plus an unparalleled sense of humor and wit – Joe leads his team to deliver the “details that make the difference” for our customers. Joe’s health IT career involves more than two decades of hands-on leadership experience. Before joining HPG, he worked at Cerner as a Solution and Technical Consultant, developing extensive expertise in Cerner applications and reporting capabilities. Joe has a Bachelor’s of Business Administration degree in Business, Management and Marketing from Park University, as well as a master’s degree in information technology from Keller Graduate School of Management of DeVry University. Krista Osborn Vice President, Human Resources & Recruiting Krista Osborn brings extensive senior leadership experience in human resources and people management, with a focus on culture and talent development, employee benefits, retention strategies, and coaching. With over 25 years of experience in the health IT consulting industry, she excels in organizational design, driving efficiencies, and leading teams through all phases of business, from start-ups to acquisitions. Krista’s unwavering commitment to excellence ensures that HPG attracts and retains top talent in the industry while delivering exceptional service to candidates, associates, and leadership alike. Before joining HPG, Krista held leadership positions including Director of HR at Health Data Specialists, LLC; and First Choice Consulting, Inc. She earned her Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration with a concentration in Human Resource Management from Wichita State University. John Pearson Chief Technology Officer and Application Services Director An accomplished health IT professional and leader, John joined HPG in 2007. John is responsible for the professional development of our Application Services and Project Management service lines. In July 2021, John added Chief Technology Officer to his title and oversees our Information Technology team and HPG’s technology infrastructure. Before becoming Application Services Director, he served in numerous capacities, including Senior Consultant, Team Leader, and Support Center Manager. Through an objective, efficient and caring leadership approach, John oversees our excellent team of Cerner Consulting Experts as they deliver the high levels of quality our customers expect. With a bachelor’s degree in computer science and mathematics from the University of Missouri-Columbia, John’s health IT career spans more than two decades. Prior to joining HPG, he worked at Cerner as a Solution Architect and Software Engineer, building deep expertise in Cerner applications and custom reporting functionalities. Kara Gartland, CPA Director of Finance Kara has been an integral part of HPG for over six years, now serving as Director of Finance and previously holding roles such as CRM Business Development Analyst, Marketing Coordinator, and gaining valuable experience in recruiting. These positions allowed her to develop a deep understanding of the company from multiple perspectives. Her hands-on leadership and financial expertise have been vital to HPG’s success, ensuring consistent support for associates, customers, and suppliers. Kara also oversees the 401K Retirement Plan, providing knowledgeable support and feedback to team members. A proud graduate of the University of Kansas, Kara holds a Master’s degree in Accounting. Her professional journey includes roles at KPMG, JMW (a boutique tax firm now combined with RubinBrown), tw-Security, and Maple Ranch Properties, each of which has contributed to her well-rounded leadership style and expertise. Scott Terstriep Regional Senior Vice President As our Regional Senior Vice President in the Central region, Scott is responsible for developing and strengthening customer relationships. Since joining our company in 2007 as a Senior Account Executive, Scott has always shown great passion and dedication to serving HPG customers and team members as well. With his outstanding ability to build and foster healthy, customer-focused relationships, Scott continually seeks new information about what healthcare organizations need with their EHR and EHR related projects and new ways to connect customers with our premier consulting services. Scott’s health IT career spans more than two decades, with a proven track record in sales, account management, leadership and business development. Prior to joining HPG, Scott specialized in sales and pharmacy workflow at ScriptPro. He has a bachelor’s degree in Business Communications from the University of Kansas. Katie Broussard Regional Vice President Katie, who joined HPG in 2015, manages and develops meaningful customer relationships as the Regional Vice President in the Central/Midwest region of the country. Katie excels at strengthening HPG’s position in her market area by focusing on the unique needs of customers and acting as a trusted advisor. Katie’s career spans more than 30 years of healthcare IT, sales management, account management, practice management, and sales processes activities. Before joining HPG, she worked as Director of Provider Inside Sales at MedeAnalytics and held Senior Account Executive positions at Covisint and Vitera Healthcare Solutions (formerly Sage Software/WebMD). Jamie McAfee Regional Vice President Jamie, who joined HPG in 2013, manages and develops customer relationships as our Regional Vice President in the West region of the country. She excels at taking a holistic approach in understanding customer needs to suggest solutions through our consulting services. Jamie’s background as a Solution Architect, combined with her consultative sales approach, enables her to find the best fit for opportunities and engage lasting relationships that offer the highest customer satisfaction. With a bachelor’s degree in biochemistry from Northwest Missouri State University and the University of Kansas, Jamie has more than a decade of experience in health IT. Before joining HPG, she was a successful Solution Architect at Oracle Cerner for almost six years, implementing clinical and revenue cycle applications, and was part of more than 50 client sites. Jamie Moore Regional Vice President Joining HPG in 2014, Jamie manages and develops customer relationships as the Regional Vice President in the Northeast region of the country. His experience in developing and leading teams, assessing operations and business needs, and providing excellent customer service is key to achieving the desired results for his customers. With a bachelor’s degree in business administration and management from Kennesaw State University, Jamie offers more than a decade of experience in management, leadership, human resources and sales. Prior to joining HPG, Jamie held HR, management and team leadership positions at such firms as Paychex and Target. Brian Weil Regional Vice President Brian, who joined HPG in 2007 as a Senior Consultant, now serves as Regional Vice President, managing and strengthening relationships with customers in the Southeast region of the country. Brian’s experience with Oracle Cerner solutions and architecture is key in his understanding of customer needs, assessing resource and solution requirements, and proposing solutions to improve and optimize EMR functionality at our customer sites. With more than 20 years in healthcare IT, Brian provides deep expertise in healthcare, Oracle Cerner, consulting, account management, sales processes, and customer relationship management. Before joining HPG, Brian worked at Oracle Cerner as both a Solution Architect and Integration Architect. Kyle Terstriep Senior Resource Development Executive Kyle joined HPG in 2010 and has contributed to our success in numerous roles, including as a CRM and Social Networking Analyst and Business Development Support Representative. In his current role as Senior Resource Development Executive, Kyle is responsible for recruiting, mentoring, developing and acquiring consulting expertise for HPG, with a deep commitment to our company and culture. Brandi Golemon, MBA Senior Resource Development Executive and Accountant Brandi joined HPG in 2010 as an accountant in the finance department. Within the Finance and HR team, she is responsible for processing payroll and providing support to our associates. Her passion for the company and dedication to enhancing employee experience led her to take on a combined role in finance and recruiting. In 2022, she joined the Senior Resource Development team, where she focuses on recruiting, mentoring, and developing consulting talent while acquiring expertise to support HPG’s growth. Brent Budke Senior Resource Development Executive Brent joined HPG in 2023. In his current role as Senior Resource Development Executive, Brent is responsible for recruiting, mentoring, developing and acquiring consulting expertise for HPG, with a deep commitment to our company and culture. 888.681.9501 info@HPGresources.com Let’s socialize! Please Click Here to View Heritage Palms Golf & Country Club (HPGCC) is structured in what is known as a Common Interest Realty Association (CIRA). This means that Heritage Palms, like other bundled golf communities, is both a country club and a homeowner’s association (HOA). The costs associated with Southwest Florida CIRA’s are similar, but the manner in which the various dues and fee are structured may differ as prescribed in each club’s legal documents (Declaration of Covenants, By Laws, Rules & Regulations). The Heritage Palms Dues and Fees are very competitive with other similar clubs considering the level of services provided, the amenities and the quality of those amenities. Master Association Closing Fee One-time fees are payable at closing.  The new Buyer is responsible for the Resale Capital Assessment Fee and Transfer Fee. The Seller is responsible for the Estoppel Fee. Resale Capital Assessment Fee - $7,500.00.  This fee is used to fund the purchase of new capital items which further enhance the community and its amenities. Membership Transfer Fee - $500.00. This fee covers the administrative cost of processing the transfer of membership. Estoppel Fee - $250.00.  This fee is charged in order to determine the status of your account. It covers the administrative cost to determine if you are current and on-track, if you are behind, or if there are any special assessments that are due by the seller. Annual Master Association Dues and Fees The Heritage Palms fiscal year is January 1-December 31. The FY25 annual dues and fees applicable to each unit total $8918. They are broken down as followed: Master Association Dues - $7,528 Basic Cable (Summit Broadband Cable and Internet) - $840 Special Assessment Fee (Capital Improvement Program)- $550 Food & Beverage (F&B) Minimum - $500. Heritage Palms requires owners to purchase a minimum amount of food and/or beverages per unit annually or be billed for the unpurchased amount on December 31.  Owners who have transfer members will be credited for the amount their tenant accrues.  The Food and Beverage Minimum is not included in the Master Association Dues. Note: Many SWFL clubs operate with a Community Development District (CDD). A CDD is established under Florida law by the developer with authority to issue bonds for the purpose of financing community infrastructure, and for the continuing maintenance and replacement of that infrastructure.  The HPCDD and Master Homeowner Association Board of Directors are two separate and distinct entities. The Heritage Palms Master Documents provide for both entities to interact with one another for the benefit of the community. In general terms, the HPCDD functions within the regulatory guidelines of Florida Statute 190 giving it special powers to maintain and build infrastructure and recreational facilities identified as belonging to the CDD. The HPCDD owns roadways, street sidewalks, conservation areas, stormwater management lakes, retention areas and entrance ways. The Master Homeowner Association is responsible for the common property as well as covenant enforcement and architectural review. Annual Neighborhood Fees Heritage Palms homes are organized in 41 separate neighborhood associations. The neighborhood associations are managed by 5 different management companies.  Each association has its own set of fees that are not included as part of the Master Association Fees. Name: * First Name Last Name E-mail: * Phone Number: ( ) - First three digits Second three digits Last four digits Please indicate if you are: Member Transfer Member To better help us assist you please indicate if you are a member or transfer member Message/ Comment: * Safety & Gatehouse Emergencies 24 hours a day, 7 days a week; for medical, fire or police emergencies, call 911; for vehicle accidents when there is damage to another’s property or injuries, call 911. After hours or on the weekends, if non-emergency assistance is needed, call the gatehouse at 239-277-9273 and the officer will direct your inquiry to the proper staff member. Please report any suspicious activity to the Gatehouse or the Fort Myers Police Department (239) 321-7700. AED Locations Location of AED’s should be in probable areas where a person may suffer a sudden cardiac arrest, SCA, as well as place the AED in a location that is easily accessible. This often turns out to be reception areas, lobbies, lunch rooms, centrally-located restrooms. Also keep in mind foot traffic patterns and places where people tend to congregate and facilities where high risk activity might occur. Our AED’s are found: Map of Locations One AED is located in the hallway of the Lodge. One AED is located in the Clubhouse near the hostess stand. One AED is located in the Golf Pro Shop hallway. One AED is located at the Clubhouse pool near the Cabana. One AED is located in the Activity Center Lobby. One AED is located in the Golf Course Maintenance oce entrance. One AED is located in the Patrol Vehicle. Permanent Visitors List: Please keep in mind that you may call, fax or e-mail the names of frequent visitors that you want to add to your permanent visitors list. By placing these names on a permanent list, you do not have to call the gatehouse each time one of these visitors enter HPGCC. Please Note: If not on a permanent visitor’s list, you must call each time you are expecting a guest. If someone comes unannounced, the gatehouse will call you. If your information, address or telephone, is not updated in the computer and we cannot get in touch with you, your guest will not be allowed in to HPGCC. Community Traffic Stop signs have been placed throughout the community. Please be safe and observe the 25 mph speed limit. For your safety and the safety of others, please refrain from walking or jogging in the community roadways. Traffic Violations Traffic violations are applicable to speeding and reckless driving within the Heritage Palms Community. This includes excessive speeding, dangerous driving and other conduct that affects the health and safety of others. Traffic violations include but are not limited to the following: • Speeding in excess of speed limits posted in the community • Running a stop sign • Ignoring round-about signage • Gate entrance and exit violation Any violations of traffic rules will result in the following disciplinary action a. First Violation - Member will be sent a warning letter b. Subsequent violations – Each subsequent violation will add 10 days to the   previous gate pass deactivation along with a $200 fine for each subsequent violation. c. More than three violations in any (12) month period may result in further enforcement actions by the Board of Directors. d. A violation by one member of the Family may result in the suspension of all other family members privileges. After two years without a violation, the process begins anew. Any subsequent violation within a two year period after a previous one, continues the disciplinary process. Parking Violations Any parking in a clearly marked no parking zone or restricted area outlined in the rules and regulations will result in the following: a. $65 fine for each violation. b. Three of more parking violations will result in larger fines and suspensions as determined by the Board of Directors. The Ft. Myers Police Department will patrol the streets of Heritage Palms Community on a regular basis and will issue tickets for parking and traffic violations. In cases where large club activities are being held with limited parking available, security may direct or permit parking in no parking areas at the Clubhouse. Lightening Warning This club has no lightning detection device or alarm system. In the event of inclement weather, golfers should immediately leave the course and seek shelter. Golfers play at their own risk. Lightning strikes may cause serious injury or death. Wildlife Please do not feed the alligators, ducks, raccoons or any other wildlife! For all wildlife inquires please contact CDD District Manager Cal Teague at 245-7118 ext. 301, (Cell) 233-4437, or via Email . Our Community consists of over 800 acres, and features two immaculate 18-hole championship golf courses designed by Azinger & Lewis. 45 freshwater lakes and ponds, lush fairways, and 179 acres of nature preserves surround our homes and facilities.  Within this gated community, there are 40 neighborhood associations including Luxury Twin Villas, 2- story Verandas, 4-story Terrace Condominiums, Single-Family Homes and Single-Family Estate Homes.  Since all 1662 owners are also members, there is an immediate intrinsic sense of camaraderie. By living here, you get to take advantage of all the amenities our Club has to offer. Golf - Heritage Palms Golf & Country Club - Fort Myers, FL Skip to content Member Login Logout Home Community Employment Visitor Management System Between the Palms News Around the Club August 2023 ARC- Architectural Review Committee About History Mission & Values Contact & Directions Club Lifestyle Golf Racquet Sports Fitness & Wellness Real Estate Dining & Events Page content Home Club Lifestyle Golf Golf Pro Shop Open Daily 6:30am to 5:00pm Heritage Palms is home to an Azinger/Lewis–designed layout featuring 36 holes of championship golf that challenge and inspire players of all levels. Our facilities include a full-service Golf Pro Shop, expansive driving range, two practice putting greens, and a variety of instructional programs and clinics led by our professional staff. To ensure every Member has convenient access to the course, we utilize the Chelsea automated tee time system, which provides a fair and efficient way for all players to enjoy the game. Royal Course Sabal Course Dress Code Golf Courses and Golf Practice Areas General: The golf course Dress Code applies to adults and juniors. Shirts and blouses designed to be tucked in shall be tucked in at all times. Shirts and blouses designed to be worn outside slacks, skirts, or shorts may be so worn. All golf shoes and golf sandals shall have soft spikes. Athletic sneakers are also acceptable as golf shoes. Bare feet are not permitted. Sweaters, jackets, golf jackets, vests and pullovers are appropriate. Blue jeans or shorts are not allowed. Men: Proper attire includes golf shirts with sleeves which are collared or mock turtle; and slacks, golf shorts or similar walking or Bermuda shorts of appropriate length. Women: Proper attire includes golf shirts or blouses which may be sleeveless, which are collared or with boat neck, v-neck, mock turtle neck or standard collars; slacks, golf shorts or similar walking or Bermuda shorts of appropriate length, skorts or golf skirts of appropriate length; slacks or capri, crop or skimmer pants. Use of the Golf Facilities Except as provided by the Governing Documents or by Rules promulgated by the Heritage Palms Board, the use of the golf courses (including age restrictions) is controlled by the Club’s General Manager and golf staff, and all Owners, transferees, guests and other golfers shall follow the directives of the General Manager and golf staff. All players, whether using a cart or walking, must register at the golf shop before playing the golf course. Except for shotgun starts and certain circumstances in which golf staff allows play to start off the 10th tee, all play must start on the first tee. No more than four players per group are permitted, unless otherwise allowed by the golf staff. All paper, bottles, cans and other trash should be placed in your golf bag or cart until you reach a trash receptacle. No coolers are allowed on the golf courses unless supplied by the Club. Each player must have a set of clubs and golf bag when playing the course. The only permitted activity on the golf courses is playing golf, and all other activities—including practicing golf, ball hawking, biking, walking or jogging and fishing, are prohibited. The General Manager may exercise discretion to provide by written notice that certain such activities may take place when a golf course is closed. Neither the Club or its staff shall have any responsibility for damage to any private property caused by any golfer. While the Club provides drop area racks for the convenience of golfers, the Club shall have no responsibility for unattended golf clubs or other equipment located at such racks or elsewhere, which responsibility will be with the owner of such clubs or equipment. GOLF CARTS No privately owned carts are allowed on the golf courses. Parking of privately owned carts in the parking lot of the main Clubhouse is subject to such restrictions as determined by management to accommodate scarce full-vehicle parking, at which times such parking at the Clubhouse shall be limited to the designated area at the driving range. Operation of golf carts on the golf courses or elsewhere in the Community is limited to licensed drivers. Carts are restricted to two riders and two bags. During normal operating conditions, the 90 degree rule is always in effect except as otherwise allowed by golf staff. Carts are to remain on cart paths until reaching a point adjacent to where the ball lies. At that point, carts may be driven across the fairway directly to the ball and should return to the cart path on the same line after the shot has been played. Cart path only restrictions on par 3s, by signage or as posted, shall be obeyed. Carts are not permitted on the shoulder or surface of any tee, green or bunker. Stakes and roped areas should be honored. Carts with approved handicapped flags, except as required by the golf staff, are not obligated to follow the 90 degree rule, and may park at the staked area provided for such carts. Those with such flags must follow the related rules. The person(s) using the cart always assumes responsibility for returning the cart in the same condition and is responsible for any damage or injury that occurs through operation of the vehicle. At day-end, carts shall be returned to the golf shop at times required by golf staff. TEE TIMES, CHELSEA AND GREEN FEE POLICIES Players must be ready to commence play at the time established by their starting time or lose their starting time. In the event of such loss, the players may not commence play until authorized by golf staff. The rules of the Chelsea tee time reservation system shall be honored, and no person shall use the membership number of another or other means to avoid any fees or the counting of plays in the Chelsea system. GOLF ETIQUETTE, CARE FOR THE COURSES, PACE OF PLAY AND RESPECT FOR RANGERS Golf is a game where courtesy and etiquette, as well as care for the golf courses, should always be observed. All golfers shall repair their ball marks on greens, sand their divots in fairways and rake their tracks before leaving a sand bunker. After finishing a hole, all golfers shall place the flag in the hole, leave the green area immediately and proceed to the next tee, waiting to mark scores at the next tee. All golfers shall be respectful of private property surrounding the golf course. Under no circumstances shall carts be driven on, or any shot played from, private property. All golfers shall maintain a pace of play that keeps them up with the group in front of them and abide the Club’s pace of play rules. Rangers and/or golf shop staff consistently monitor the speed of play and are required to enforce the Club’s pace of play rules for the enjoyment of the entire field. All golfers shall be obedient and respectful to the directions of the Club’s rangers, who are authorized to impose the following requirements. First Warning - The group has fallen behind the group in front of them and has fallen behind the allotted time limit for their position on the course. The ranger will ask the group to catch up with the group in front of them or better their time. Second Warning - The group has not improved their position. The ranger will approach the group and inform them of their second warning and that the next warning will require them to move to the next tee. Third Warning - The group has been warned properly and has not improved their position. The ranger will escort the group to the next tee. Pace of Play As most members are aware, last year we asked our golf rangers to be more active in the Club’s goal of 4 hour and 10 minute rounds. As season approaches, the rangers are again being asked to be more active, and we are asking you to: Keep up with the group ahead of you. There should never be a group with an open fairway ahead. In such a situation, your group must hasten play. When approached by beverage carts, wait until you have left the green to be served, moving rapidly to the tee after being served. The concession operators have been asked to adhere to this procedure. Carts and extra clubs must be left on the cart path side of the green when putting at locations which allow golfers to walk to their carts or clubs in the direction of the next tee box, and not in the direction of on-coming golfers. Record scores from the preceding hole at the next tee box, rather than on or near the green when a following group is waiting to approach. Play ready golf (Ready Golf Rules-pdf), on the tee, fairway and green. When the course is crowded, there is no reason for golfers on opposite sides of fairways not to be in position and ready to take their shot. Also, if your cart partner is hitting, be prepared to fill his or her divot. When putting, be ready to put when the golfer preceding you has putted. On the tee, be ready to drive (club in hand--out of your cart) when the preceding golfer has hit. Do not take undue time to locate a lost ball. No ball hawking. The rangers have been asked to instruct groups falling behind to pick up the pace and, if the pace is not adequately picked up, to pick up their balls and proceed to the next tee. While this may make some feel pushed, it is necessary so that the entire field is not held up when the pace is delayed by one group. We have asked the rangers to be respectful and courteous, but firm. We ask the members to adhere to the instructions of the rangers. If a golfer has a complaint about a ranger, the complaint should be communicated, in person or by writing, to the pro shop. Our rules forbid members from disrespecting or being abusive to any Club employees, including rangers. The failure to abide the request of the rangers, as well as disrespectful or abusive language or treatment of the rangers, can give rise to disciplinary action--including suspension of golfing privileges. You should see a ranger at least two times during your round and feel free to advise the ranger of undue delays. However, if you are in a fast playing group and are on or under a 4 hour 10 minute pace, please remember that the membership is of diverse playing skills and many find it difficult to play at a pace faster than our standard pace of play. Club Lifestyle - Heritage Palms Golf & Country Club - Fort Myers, FL Skip to content Member Login Logout Home Community Employment Visitor Management System Between the Palms News Around the Club August 2023 ARC- Architectural Review Committee About History Mission & Values Contact & Directions Club Lifestyle Golf Racquet Sports Fitness & Wellness Real Estate Dining & Events Page content Home Club Lifestyle Amenities Clubhouse Centrally located overlooking the 38-acre lake and Sabal 18 Green, this facility houses our Administration offices, the Palms Dining Room and Grill Room. Palms Dining Room The Palms Dining Room is located in our newly renovated Clubhouse. It boasts a picturesque view through expansive windows overlooking our 38-acre lake, making it the perfect place to enjoy a dinner with friends, neighbors and guests. The restaurant offers upscale fine dining, with a wide range of selections prepared by our Executive Chef. The extensive menu features extraordinary buffets, and theme nights sure to please everyone. Grill Room The Grill Room is open every day for lunch and dinner, and offers a more casual dining experience. The restaurant offers lighter fare, ranging from soups, appetizers and salads to burgers and sandwiches. Pizza is also on the menu prepared in our new double stack conveyor belt pizza oven. The Grill Room sports a huge, well-stocked bar, eighteen ceiling fans, and thirteen televisions for your viewing pleasure.  Join us indoors or in the open air on our enclosed, roofed patio graced by a gas fireplace. Lodge The Lodge is a private 5,000 square foot Clubhouse available only to members and transfer members. It provides a grand-hall for member events and social activities. It houses a card room, art room, bocce courts and a poolside Tiki Bar & Grill. The resort swimming pool, waterfall and spa area is our main social watering hole. Tiki Bar & Grill The Tiki Bar & Grill is located poolside at the Lodge and is open daily for breakfast, lunch and dinner. It boasts its own full-service bar and kitchen, offering an expanded bar and grill menu including healthy choice entrees. In season, live entertainment is featured every Friday night. Cabana The Cabana is open daily to members and guests. This snack house is located by the Clubhouse pool and can easily serve pool users, golfers, tennis players and other guests. The Cabana offers delicious breakfast sandwiches, a light lunch menu, snacks, and beverages. Activity Center The first floor is home to a state-of-the-art fitness area, aerobics room, and men’s and ladies’ locker rooms. The Cardio and Strength Training Room contains ten televisions and forty pieces of equipment including thirteen newly purchased Precor Resolute strength machines, two new weight benches and a full rack of new free weights ranging from 5lbs to 50lbs, seven treadmills, six elliptical machines, four recumbent bikes, a StairMaster, Expresso bike, Aeridyne (airbike), a rowing machine, and a multipurpose machine. The Aerobics Studio is equipped with a suspended wood floor, mirrored walls, ballet bars and spectacular large windows.  Group Fitness and Aqua Aerobics classes are offered complimentary to members. Personal training with Corrective Exercise Specialists is offered, as well as Massages.. The second floor houses a large multipurpose room which was designed to offer maximum flexibility and is available for meetings, events, and social activities. Furnished to accommodate 96, it can also be partitioned into three separate, smaller rooms, each of which has counters, sinks and electrical outlets to facilitate just about any activity. Located on the other half of the second floor is the Library, dedicated game room and conference room, as well as restrooms. Golf Heritage Palms is an Azinger/Lewis designed layout that features 36 holes of  championship golf courses, a full service Golf Pro Shop, Driving Range, golf instruction and clinics, and two practice putting greens. We also offer the Chelsea automated tee time system.  It provides an equitable system allowing all members convenience and accessibility to enjoy playing our golf courses. Tennis Tennis enthusiast of all ages and levels join us on one of the eight-lighted Har-Tru courts for tournament play, social, teaching or charity events. The Tennis Shop and onsite Tennis Professionals will give you the resources you need to have fun and improve your skills. Our goal is to provide Heritage Palms Members and their Guests with the best tennis experience. We offer a wide range or tennis services, lessons, clinics and products. Pools In addition to the Clubhouse pool and the Lodge pool, there are seven additional community pools within Heritage Palms.  All pool hours are dawn to dusk. 				                     				                     				                         2 Bath Heritage Palms Golf & Country Club Heritage Palms Golf & Country Club is a premier gated and bundled golf community located in Fort Myers, Florida. This expansive community spans over 800 acres and includes two 18-hole championship golf courses designed by Azinger & Lewis, offering residents exceptional golfing experiences surrounded by 45 freshwater lakes and ponds, lush fairways, and 179 acres of nature preserves. Heritage Palms is not just a home, it is a lifestyle! The community is composed of 40 neighborhood associations, featuring a variety of housing options including Luxury Twin Villas, two-story Verandas, four-story Terrace Condominiums, Single-Family Homes, and Single-Family Estate Homes. With 1,662 homeowners, all of whom are members of the club, the community fosters a strong sense of camaraderie. Living in Heritage Palms means that residents not only enjoy beautiful surroundings and a welcoming community but also have access to a wide range of amenities offered by the Club, making it an ideal place for those who appreciate both luxury and an active lifestyle.
